Fed opens the floodgate. Green light for rotation heading into the second half of 2025. Our number one theme and something we had long been pounding the table on was housing. With sentiment at multi-year lows, we laid out our thesis and highlighted the catalyst. A 4 million plus unit housing shortage after more than a decade of underbuilding. 70 plus million millennials entering prime family formation years. Favorable policies and regulations and easing mortgage rates on the horizon. Rather than owning the waring fashions of homebuilders trapped in a race to the bottom of incentive wars, we played the theme with a handful of levered arms dealers, two of which we will touch on later. Fast forward to today, all of those catalysts remain firmly intact. The only change is that Fed and J. Powell have done a complete about face, effectively giving the sector a green light. For months, we've argued that the Fed has been well over 100 basis points too restrictive, hurting housing, and forcing millions of millennials to put their lives on hold.

QXO update. QXO is up 60% since we discussed it on Fox Business a couple of months ago on April 4th and even more since we first cover it on the podcast. Not only is QXO one of our favorite levered arms dealer plays on housing, it is also a bet on one of, if not the best jockeyies in the business. Brad Jacobs. Brad Jacobs track record speaks for itself. An investment in XPO when he got involved would have been a 50 bagger. United Rentals would have been closer to a 200 bagger. Taken together, investing alongside Jacobs across his companies would have generated more than a 300x bagger. Simply put, Brad Jacobs is in a league of his own when it comes to consistently creating shareholder value at scale. So, when Jacobs spots an industry ripe for disruption, you pay attention. And that's exactly what we see with QXO. His next venture as he aims to build a $50 billion plus powerhouse in the $800 billion building products distribution industry. After laying out the playbook, QXO is finally  getting the recognition it deserves. The only difference is we are already closing in on a double from our cost basis while the rest of Wall Street is just catching on. Now they're all taking price targets up to as high as $50. QXO's recent earnings report was the first since the Beacon acquisition included two months of combined operations. Revenues of 1.91 billion beat consensus of 1.87 billion while EPS of 11 cents came ahead of 7 cents expectations. More importantly, Jacobs and his team continue to identify opportunities with beacon integration that exceeded initial expectations. Management remains confident in at least doubling legacy beacon Ibida organically while also driving over 500 basis points of margin expansion. Early signs of the Jacobs Midas touch are already visible with adjusted Ebida margins of 10.7% running well ahead of the 2005 pre-acquisition consensus of 9.8%. For those concerned about QXO walking away from the GMS deal and Lowe's 8.8 billion FBM acquisition, it's important to burden ourselves with the facts. At the end of the day, this is an 800 billion industry with over 7,000 distributors across North America, making it one of the most fragmented markets out there.
